div1.p: Carter cautions Laura Armistead Carter about tuberculosis.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 18, 1911
div1.p:
If Tremfsey has no cough. She
cannot convey tubercular infection even if
she has tuberculosis of lungs. If she has
any cough & has t of l, it is possible for
her to convey it. Who examined her for
tuberculosis? That is an extremely im-
portant point.

By all means go on to h.R. & return
to Portsmouth or not as may after
wards seems proper. If Tremfsey has
a cough you should not sleep with her
& if she has had a cough long - I doubt the ad-
visability of your occupying the room in which
she sleeps & has slept at your Aunt Louise's, atI would
h. R. be unwilling to expose you to tubercular
infection in your - present state of health.
L Sleeping in the same room isn't so bad
what I understand by sleeping together is occu-
pying the same bed.

How much of a “spitting of blood” was
it? Above all, what physician examined
her?

You & she go as to h. R. & you can occu-
py one or two rooms as the case may require & clean up your
own rooms. It will do her good anyway
all well
div1.closer:
your affec'ate father H. R. Carter PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND.
, 190 .
Surgeon.
